//: This is assumed to be modern production Sevillian 174 gr boat tailed hollo point cartridges. The default ammo type for .303 weapons, cause these are far more common than surplus military Mk VII rounds.
description: Modern manufactured spitzered .303 calibre cartridges, loaded with 174 GR boat-tailed hollo-point bullets.  Starting life as a black powder cartridge in service with British Long Lee rifles in the early nineteenth century, the cartridge evolved into a centre-fired smokeless-powder design and became the standard rifle and machinegun cartridge of the British commonwealth, until it was phased out by 7.62mm NATO.  The round’s boat tail design gives it greater stability with lese aerial drag over long ranges, making it favourable for competition shooting, whilst the bullet’s hollow-point construction leaves behind larger wound channels when used in an offensive roll.

Modern manufactured single-core soft-point .303 calibre cartridges, loaded with 180 GR exposed led bullets.  Starting life as a black powder cartridge in service with British Long Lee rifles in the early nineteenth century, the cartridge evolved into a centre-fired smokeless-powder design and became the standard rifle and machinegun cartridge of the British commonwealth, until it was phased out by 7.62mm NATO.  The bullet features an open-tipped design manufactured from soft led, allowing the round to undergo greater expansion upon making contact with targets, leading to larger wound channels and greater overall terminal performance.

Modern manufactured full metal jacketed .303 calibre cartridges, loaded with 174 GR single-core boat tailed bullets.  Starting life as a black powder cartridge in service with British Long Lee rifles in the early nineteenth century, the cartridge evolved into a centre-fired smokeless-powder design and became the standard rifle and machinegun cartridge of the British commonwealth, until it was phased out by 7.62mm NATO.  Featuring a boat tailed design, which allows the round to retain greater terminal performance and stability over longer ranges, the bullet possesses a solid metal jacket that grants it the capability to punch through thicker material at the cost of virtually non-existent expansion.
